mxCell.value: Our program is executed line by line in order, with no gaps or pauses between each step
Our program waits to execute some code until an event occurs
How do we know if code is async?
Run some code to do a task
Can we run other code during this time?  If so, it is async!
Determining whether two words are anagrams of eachother
Setting up an event handler on a button, then waiting for a user to click it
Loading a list of blog posts from a remote server, then printing the number of posts
Fetching an image from an online source, then showing it in the DOM
Nothing else can happen during this time!
Tell the browser to call 'onSubmit' when the form is submitted
We are free to run other code at this point!
If we do have to run a really long calculation, there are tools to make sure we don't lock up the UI
Callbacks don't magically make our code async
This means that all Javascript code is sync in nature
In theory, event handlers cant work with JS - but they do!  So how?
Promises are used to help us make network requests to fetch info from JS code
Promises can be confusing, but they really just come down to understanding a handful of rules
We are going to look at promises in isolation - without network requests
Similar in nature to callback functions.  We use them to run some code when something happens in the future
You will say 'this is boring and whats the point' in the next few videos :)
Instead of resolving with one value and having that be passed to every .then, each .then should be called with the previous .then's return value
Instead of rejecting with one value and having that be passed to every .catch, each .catch should be called with the previous .catch's return value
Calling '.then' or '.catch' should return the promise.  This will allow us to chain additional .then and .catch statements on
If a .then or .catch returns a promise, and the next .then is chained on, don't run the next .then until that new promise is resolved
Function that is passed to an event listener
When event occurs, callback is invoked
Callback running is a sign that something happened.
Callback running doesn't necessarily mean that something good or bad happened
Object that is used to organize callbacks
We can register a 'success' callback and a 'fail' callback
Promise runs the 'success' callback when something good happens
Promise runs the 'fail' callback when something bad happens
A promise is an object that keeps track of one or more callback functions
We're still waiting on something to happen
Save this callback function.  Call it one time when something good happens
Save this callback function.  Call it one time when something bad happens
Something good happened!  Call all the callbacks that have been saved with 'then'.  Call them with this 'value'. Also, update 'status' to 'resolved'
Something bad happened!  Call all the callbacks that have been saved with 'catch'.  Call them with this 'value'.  Also, update 'status' to 'rejected'
A promise can only go from 'pending' to 'resolved' or 'rejected' one time
If 'then' is called after a promise has been 'resolved', call the callback immediately
If 'catch' is called after a promise has been 'rejected', call the callback immediately
